[]Author: David St;
Rating: 5
When: 4 months ago
Great hotel near the Vatican. The hotel was close to public transport and where the locals ate. So getting an authentic Local experience and food was simple.

Author: Amanda Rose;
Rating: 4
When: a year ago
Overall we enjoyed our experience. Rooms were clean and nice. Staff met accommodations. We only ate there for morning breakfast which was the same each morning. Not many additional amenities to the hotel. Very close to Vatican but far from other tourists stops

Author: M G;
Rating: 4
When: a year ago
Elegant hotel located on a 5 minute walk from St. Peter's square. We received a room upgrade upon arrival, which was a nice gesture. If possible get a room with balcony as you can see the Dome from there. The hotel is spotlessly clean and the room was spacious and well-equipped as compared to other Rome hotels we have visited. The hotel's staff was courteous and welcoming (apart for some of the waitresses at the restaurant, who were not very attentive - e.g. they would not ask if you need anything like espresso). The hotel is in a very convenient and quiet location. One thing that could be improved is the breakfast - while the variety was satisfactory, it was one and the same each morning. The New Year's buffet dinner was a bit of a disappointment - the mood was not particularly festive and it closed before the start of the new year. Food was also a bit on the bland side.

Author: Bob P.;
Rating: 4
When: a year ago
Great location near everything! Friendly staff with good english. That's important to me since I'm totally ignorant of other languages. I might have been " put on the elevator" a bit due to a "reservation foul-up" that wouldn't make the room price I had reserved available for 2 days. They gave me an "upgraded" room for the first 2 days for the original price but said I would either have to move to the cheaper room after that or pay the upgraded price to stay in the original room. I decided to stay put. Who wants to pack up and move? Long story short it might have been a simple bait and switch type of thing, but I'm not sure. Oh, the room is nice but I don't know what the "upgrade might be". Recommend none the less.

Author: Kate Heltemes;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
This was our favorite hotel of our European vacation. Very clean and spacious, although I think we had one of the better rooms. Bathroom was great. We had a balcony in the room and a balcony in the bathroom. We did some sink laundry and let it dry in the balcony. This was our plan so we wouldn't have to pack as much clothing. It was easy to catch an uber or taco from this hotel. Walking distance to the subway which was easy to use. We were able to travel to many destinations by walking it taking the subway. I recommend getting a subway ticket that includes unlimited rides for x amount of time. I think we did 48 hours. Breakfast had many options and was very good. While Rome itself was very dirty with trash pretty much all over this hotel was very clean inside and out. I would definitely return to this hotel.

[]Author: Carlo Carlevale;
Rating: 4
When: a month ago
It is one of the oldest scientific institutions in Europe. It was founded in Rome in 1603 by Federico Cesi, Francesco Stelluti, Anastasio De Filiis and Johannes van Heeck, in order to establish a meeting place for the development of the sciences. Its name refers to the sharpness that must have the sight of those who dedicate themselves to the sciences, to the future and to human progress, a property that characterizes the lynx, in relation to sight. The Accademia dei Lincei has undergone many changes over time. After a first period of great prestige, due to the work of Cesi and the other founders and to the presence of partners such as Galileo Galilei and Giovanni Battista Della Porta, after Cesi's death in 1630, the Academy reduced its activities to almost to disappear. Only in 1847 there was a real resumption of its activities by Pope Pius IX who re-founded it in the Pontifical Academy of the Nuovi Lincei, which still exists today. Subsequently from 1936 with the name of Pontifical Academy of Sciences. Since 1986 the Accademia dei Lincei has been governed by a Statute which provides for it to be composed of 540 academics, divided according to three qualifications. Therefore 180 are the "national" ordinary members, 180 the "foreign" ordinary members and 180 are the "corresponding" members. All members are then divided into two classes: the first is that of Physical Sciences, while the second is that of Moral Sciences. Since 2001 the Physical Sciences Class is divided into 5 categories, while the Moral Sciences Class is divided into 7 categories. The academy is located in the Villa Farnesina, in Rome; it was built between 1506 and 1512 by the young Peruzzi for the very wealthy Sienese banker Agostino Chigi, a great patron and prominent figure in early 16th century Rome, who had amassed a large fortune from the proceeds of the sale of the Tolfa alum and who enjoyed the protection of Pope Julius II first, and then Leo X. The Farnesina, which at the time was simply called Villa Chigi, was the first suburban noble villa in Rome and had a great prominence from the beginning, soon being cited and imitated. The architectural interventions, although they could be considered completed in 1512, continued for other works until 1520. With the death of Chigi, in 1520, the villa declined and was depleted of furnishings and works of art. In 1580 it was purchased by Cardinal Alessandro Farnese and thus had its current name. An unrealized project dates back to this period to connect Palazzo Farnese with the Farnesina with a covered passage. In 1714 it became the property of the Bourbons of Naples and in 1864 the ambassador Bermudez de Castro settled there, who, two years later, promoted a series of heavy restorations. In 1884 the opening of the Lungotevere involved the destruction of a part of the gardens and of the loggia on the river, which perhaps had been designed by Raphael. As already mentioned, it has belonged to the Italian State since 1927, which had it restored in 1929 -1942 to be assigned to the Academy of Italy and on several occasions in 1969-1983. Today it is used by the Accademia dei Lincei as a representative office and houses, on the first floor, the national print cabinet.

Author: JUZER KAPADIA;
Rating: 5
When: a month ago
The wealthy Sienese banker Agostino Chigi commissioned this villa in 1508 for his lavish banquets and for sojourns with the courtesan Imperia, who allegedly inspired one of the Three Graces painted by Raphael in the Loggia of Cupid and Psyche. Designed by the Sienese architect Baldassare Peruzzi, the harmonious Farnesina, with a central block and projecting wings, is one of the first true Renaissance villas. Peruzzi decorated some of the interiors himself, such as the Sala della Prospettiva upstairs, in which illusionistic frescoes create the impression of looking out over Rome through a marble colonnade. The painted vault of the Sala di Galatea shows the position of the stars at the time of Chigi‚Äôs birth. After his death, the banking business collapsed, and in 1577 the villa was sold to the Farnese family.

I spent over a week in Rome with my boyfriend. As much as I love Italian food, I need a good comfort American food. The burger was delicious as well as the fries! There‚Äôs plenty of selection in terms of beer and wine. Great escape if you need a little comfort food.

Author: Ben Carlo;
Rating: 4
When: 5 months ago
Is it a full-blown Denny's All-American Grand Slam? No. But this is one of the more American breakfasts around Rome. Think the continental breakfast you might get at a hotel back in the states. It's good, it satiates that craving for pancakes and sausage, but you won't be whistling the national anthem on the way out. The restaurant is cool and definitely had an American vibe, aside from the Tabacchi inside the from door. Generous indoor and outdoor seating, even in this, the age of Corona. Overall, good! You won't be transported back to America, but you will experience a satisfying nostalgia.

[]Author: Stefano Manzo;
Rating: 4
When: 6 months ago
The Fountain of the Chancellery, fully functional and with a somewhat unusual shape, is located in the VI district (Parione), leaning against a wall of a building near the Piazza della Cancelleria. History: The Fontanella is one of those created by Publio Morbiducci, winner of a competition promoted by the Governorate of Rome, in 1928, for the replacement of some cast iron fountains, with others of greater decoration. It was made entirely of travertine, a stone that is the symbol of the city of Rome. It was inaugurated on October 28, 1929. Description of the Work: The fountain is placed on a small rectangular porphyry rise, bordered by travertine which also determines an area of ‚Äã‚Äãrespect, has a particular predominantly triangular configuration, which rests on two cylinders placed at the sides, in the lower part and is surmounted by a hemisphere with four wedges In the center there is an oval medallion, surmounted by a cardinal's hat and a cross and two bas-reliefs inside, the upper one representing a griffin symbol of the Parione district, in which there is the fountain and in the lower part a flower-shaped tile , in the center of which there is a curved cinnamon from which the water flows out and pours into a small rectangular basin, with the features of a small Roman sarcophagus, where on the front side on a scroll is the inscription SPQR NOTE on the state of conservation of the work: It is discreet even if it requires the removal of limestone encrustations and in my opinion a larger area of ‚Äã‚Äãrespect should be created, perhaps with columns joined by iron bars, to prevent the parking of cars or scooters less than one meter away. NOTE FOUNTAINS IN ROME The fountains in Rome are one of the characteristic elements of the Eternal City, some say it is the city with the most fountains in the world. They have been an important element since ancient Rome, today in addition to the typical cast iron fountains called "nasoni" (around 2000), there are very beautiful ones located in the most diverse places, such as villas, squares, streets, courtyards and more. Some were made by the greatest artistic geniuses of all time, one name above all Gian Lorenzo Bernini. The importance they have in street furniture is also evidenced by the admiring glances of tourists and by the fact that they also have the social utility of quenching thirst after perhaps a long walk in the sun.

Author: Tony Popa;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
The Museo di Roma is a museum in Rome, Italy, part of the network of Roman civic museums. The museum was founded in the Fascist era with the aim of documenting the local history and traditions of the "old Rome" that was rapidly disappearing, but following many donations and acquisitions of works of art is now principally an art museum. The collections initially included 120 water-colours by the nineteenth-century painter Ettore Roesler Franz of Roma sparita, "vanished Rome", later moved to the Museo di Roma in Trastevere.

[]Author: Stefano Manzo;
Rating: 4
When: 2 years ago
In Via della Posta Vecchia is located in the district VI (Parione), between the picturesque Piazza De 'Massimi and Piazza Navona, it is a small quaint fountain in its simplicity. It is leaning against a wall of the palace through a rectangular slab of white granite, in the upper part adorned on the sides by two bas-reliefs that represent flowers, always at the top but in the middle there is a cartouche with the inscription: S.P.Q.R. 1872 Where the initials S.P.Q.R. Latin Senatvs PopvlvsQve Romanvs - the Senate and the Roman People, as the year 1872 is the year of construction. As I said the fountain is very simple a small cinnamon, inserted in a circular panel, which pours water into a tray which is also circular but partially embedded (supported by an iron support like a modiglione), unfortunately the pan has the chipped edge in the front part, the water then falls into a collection basin on the ground of the semicircular shape. To access it, there is a step always semicircular in shape, paved (like the basin) with the characteristic cobblestones, which act together with metal columns from delimiters of the area of ‚Äã‚Äãrespect. Not to be missed a few meters away, two sacred 17th century aedicules.

quotes:
[]Author: Father Kenny Ang;
Rating: 5
When: 6 months ago
This is one of my favorite churches in Rome, since I especially love Caravaggio and his works. Every time I come here, I almost always head directly to the Contarelli chapel just to delight in his three paintings of St. Matthew. My favorite one is the Calling of St. Matthew on the left-side wall of the chapel (which is the darker side of the wall, unfortunately). When I went there yesterday, some ladies already put some euros into the machine so the entire chapel was brightly illuminated. I was a lucky pilgrim and photographer!

Author: Veranika Tsybulskaya;
Rating: 5

Spectacular! Definitely worth to visit not only for a Caravaggio works, but for an ambience itself. Rich and spaced. Were lucky to end up there during the organ mass - truly recommend!

[]Author: Stefano Bucciarelli;
Rating: 4
When: 5 months ago
I would have liked... I would have paid to watch the spectacle of the carriages, wagons and carts passing through the old narrow streets without pavement of vanished Rome. As their number increased dramatically, many of the fountains the city had equipped itself with, which reduced the carriageway, began to create problems. Moving them for traffic reasons was a widespread practice and via della Scrofa follows exactly the layout of an ancient Roman road and the fountain of the same name has not escaped the rule. But the memory of it remains in a bas-relief left in its original position, along the facade of the building that was the convent of the Augustinians. While not far away, right at the corner with via dei Portoghesi, there is now the small hanging tub with the superimposition of a simple cinnamon, from which a jet of fresh water comes out. It is protected by three small columns connected to each other by two iron bars.

Author: Stefano Manzo;
Rating: 5
When: 2 years ago
The Fontana della Scrofa (located in the street of the same name) is located in the VIII Eustachio district, once it was in the position, where today there is a bas-relief depicting a sow. In the fifteenth century the bas-relief was walled up and at the end of the sixteenth century it was transformed into a fountain with the addition of a small basin. In 1874 with Rome became the capital of Italy, the traffic in the area increased dramatically and therefore was a hindrance, so the bas-relief remained at its original point, while the fountain itself was moved a short distance to the corner of the street with Via dei Pellegrini . The above is indicated in an inscription placed below the bas-relief: IN THIS PLACE IT WAS PLACED FOUNTAIN MOVED TO THE CORNER OF THE VIA DEI PORTOGHESI IN THE YEAR 1874 The fountain then placed at the aforementioned corner is made up of a small nozzle, from which the water that flows onto the cup-shaped basin comes out, from which in turn the water arrives in a collection basin on the ground. Three columns connected by bars that serve as an area of ‚Äã‚Äãprotection are placed as protection.

Author: Alessandro Romanella;
Rating: 4
When: 3 years ago
The "real" fountain of the Scrofa existed in the same street that takes its name, and was built in 1580 at the behest of Pope Gregory XIII. In 1873 it was moved because it caused considerable obstruction to traffic. The bas-relief was left in its original position, and instead the small cup-shaped hanging basin was moved a little further on, just at the corner with Via dei Portoghesi.

Author: Stefano Bucciarelli;
Rating: 4
When: 5 months ago
It characterizes the square Every time I try the history books, I rub my eyes to reread the events of this city. In Piazza Nicosia, suffocated by parked cars, there is the beautiful fountain designed by Giacomo Della Porta. Not just any one, because in Rome there are many works that bear his signature. But this one is not like the others and it was not as we see it today, because it was originally located in Piazza del Popolo, long before Valadier dedicated himself to it heart and soul with his genius. What we see remains: the elevated octagonal basin, the elegant balustrade in cipollino marble and a basin decorated with heraldic emblems. Only three small columns connected by two iron bars protect it from modernity.

Author: Maria Tanasa;
Rating: 5
When: 8 months ago
The fountain in Piazza Nicosia was originally located in Piazza del Popolo, was built in 1572 by Giacomo della Porta for Pope Gregory XIII Boncompagni, whose dragon we note on the basin, to inaugurate the restoration of the Virgin Aqueduct. When Giuseppe Valadier carried out the current restyling of the Piazza del Popolo in 1823, it was demolished to be relocated to Piazza Nicosia in 1950, when renovation work was carried out on the area coordinated by the architect Marcello Piacentini.

Author: Stefano Manzo;
Rating: 3
When: 2 years ago
The Fontana del Trullo was designed by Giacomo Della Porta in 1572. Today it is located in Piazza Nicosia, it was placed here in 1950 (after having been dismantled for several years in the warehouses of the municipality). Very beautiful is the octagonal basin, raised by two steps of the same shape, is the only original part left, the rest are reconstructions. Fortunately it is protected by an area of ‚Äã‚Äãrespect delimited by columns, connected with iron bars. Unfortunately, the vehicles parked around and the small size of the Piazza, do not give the right emphasis to the work.

Great hotel near the Vatican. The hotel was close to public transport and where the locals ate. So getting an authentic Local experience and food was simple.

Author: Amanda Rose;
Rating: 4
When: a year ago
Overall we enjoyed our experience. Rooms were clean and nice. Staff met accommodations. We only ate there for morning breakfast which was the same each morning. Not many additional amenities to the hotel. Very close to Vatican but far from other tourists stops

Author: M G;
Rating: 4
When: a year ago
Elegant hotel located on a 5 minute walk from St. Peter's square. We received a room upgrade upon arrival, which was a nice gesture. If possible get a room with balcony as you can see the Dome from there. The hotel is spotlessly clean and the room was spacious and well-equipped as compared to other Rome hotels we have visited. The hotel's staff was courteous and welcoming (apart for some of the waitresses at the restaurant, who were not very attentive - e.g. they would not ask if you need anything like espresso). The hotel is in a very convenient and quiet location. One thing that could be improved is the breakfast - while the variety was satisfactory, it was one and the same each morning. The New Year's buffet dinner was a bit of a disappointment - the mood was not particularly festive and it closed before the start of the new year. Food was also a bit on the bland side.

Author: Bob P.;
Rating: 4
When: a year ago
Great location near everything! Friendly staff with good english. That's important to me since I'm totally ignorant of other languages. I might have been " put on the elevator" a bit due to a "reservation foul-up" that wouldn't make the room price I had reserved available for 2 days. They gave me an "upgraded" room for the first 2 days for the original price but said I would either have to move to the cheaper room after that or pay the upgraded price to stay in the original room. I decided to stay put. Who wants to pack up and move? Long story short it might have been a simple bait and switch type of thing, but I'm not sure. Oh, the room is nice but I don't know what the "upgrade might be". Recommend none the less.

Author: Kate Heltemes;
Rating: 5
When: a year ago
This was our favorite hotel of our European vacation. Very clean and spacious, although I think we had one of the better rooms. Bathroom was great. We had a balcony in the room and a balcony in the bathroom. We did some sink laundry and let it dry in the balcony. This was our plan so we wouldn't have to pack as much clothing. It was easy to catch an uber or taco from this hotel. Walking distance to the subway which was easy to use. We were able to travel to many destinations by walking it taking the subway. I recommend getting a subway ticket that includes unlimited rides for x amount of time. I think we did 48 hours. Breakfast had many options and was very good. While Rome itself was very dirty with trash pretty much all over this hotel was very clean inside and out. I would definitely return to this hotel.
